title: RBC Bearings Inc (ROLL) Q3 2019 Earnings Conference Call Transcript
callText:
Image source: The Motley Fool.

RBC Bearings Inc  (NASDAQ:ROLL)Q3 2019 Earnings Conference CallFeb. 05, 2019, 11:00 a.m. ET
Contents:

Prepared Remarks
Questions and Answers
Call ParticipantsSee all our earnings call transcripts.



Trending

Guess Who Just Became Amazon's Biggest Shipper
3 Hot Growth Stocks I'd Buy Right Now
3 Reasons People Don't Use Annuities the Way They Were Meant to Be Used


Prepared Remarks:
Operator
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Third Quarter 2019 RBC Bearings Earnings Conference Call. At this time, all participants are in a listen-only mode. Later, we will conduct a question-and-answer session and instructions will follow at that time. (Operator Instructions) As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded.
I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference, Mr. Chris Donovan with the Alpha IR Group. Sir, you may begin.
Chris Donovan -- Investor Relations
Thanks, Lauren and good morning and thank you for joining us for RBC Bearings fiscal 2019 third quarter earnings conference call. With me on the call today are Dr. Michael J. Hartnett, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer and Daniel A. Bergeron, Vice President, Chief Financial Officer and Chief Operating Officer.
Before beginning today's call, let me remind you that some of the statements made today will be forward-looking and are made under the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Actual results may differ materially from those projected or implied due to a variety of factors. We refer you to RBC Bearings' recent filings with the SEC for a more detailed discussion of the risks that could impact the Company's future operating results and financial condition. These factors are also described in greater detail in the press release on the Company's website. In addition, reconciliation between GAAP and non-GAAP financial information is included as part of the release and is available on the Company's website.
Now I'll turn the call over to Dr. Hartnett.
Michael J. Hartnett -- Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer
Thank you, Chris and good morning, and welcome everyone. Net sales for the third quarter of fiscal 2019 were $171.5 million versus $166.9 million for the same period last year. Excluding the sales from businesses that we are sold or discontinued and that is Sargent Canada and Avborne Miami, organic growth for the quarter was 6.5%.
For the third fiscal quarter of 2019, sales of industrial products represented 38.4% of our net sales with aerospace products representing 61.6%. Gross margin for the quarter was $68.1 million, or 39.7% of net sales. This compares to $64.8 million, or 38.8% for the same period last year, a 5.2% increase. Adjusted operating income was $36.6 million versus an adjusted $34.4 million last year, 21.4% of sales. Adjusted EBITDA was $47.9 million, 27.9% of revenues. The business performed very well in the quarter despite many supply chain constraints, both internal and external that played several of the aerospace divisions.
Industrial products showed a 6.7% year-over-year organic sales growth rate during the period and were up 10.7% organically year-to-date. Industrial OEM was up 9.9% and distribution and aftermarket was flat versus last year's third quarter. Mining, oil and gas, machine tool and general industrial equipment continued to show strength during the period. It looks to us now that year-over-year comps will get tougher as these businesses should demonstrate a more historical growth rate of 2 times GDP going forward. This requires good basic blocking and tackling every day at the ground level and that's something that's right in our warehouse.
The days of extreme demand for our industrial products that we've seen for the last 24 months seem to be behind us for now. But on the other hand, these markets are most difficult for us to forecast and can present big upside surprises based upon market changes and commodity prices tied to oil and metals as we have seen so many times in the past. We are very well positioned to service this demand level should be -- if we be presented with the opportunity.
Aerospace and defense sales were up 6.4% on an organic basis. Shipments on the defense side can be lumpy quarter-to-quarter depending upon program timing and that's certainly happened in this quarter. Aero OEM alone was up 9.1% attributed to the increased build rate and new content at the major airframe and engine producers. As you know, the majors are reporting another major step up in build rates for FY20, supply chain constraints internal and external continue to plague the industry and impact RBC throughout fiscal '19, as mentioned in previous calls.
We are a long way toward internalizing these processes and will be phasing an additional process capability and capacity later this quarter in our fourth quarter, as we bring another 150,000 square feet of manufacturing space on line in four separate plant sites. It will be fully commissioned in the first and second quarters of FY20 and it will be begin to be phased in the later half of our Q4 FY19. And this is to ensure and renew our ability to support the next slate of our growth plan for the next fiscal year in aircraft products.
As discussed in earlier calls, primary aerospace platforms that we will see growth continue to be the 737 MAX, the A320, 787, 777X and the Joint Strike Fighter and, of course the supporting engine programs of leap and gear turbo fan.
Regarding our fourth quarter, we are expecting sales over the period to be between $178 million and $180 million compared to $175 million last year, and that's net of Canada and Airtomic Miami.
I'll now turn the call over to Dan for a more detail on the financial performance.
Daniel A. Bergeron -- Director, Vice President, Chief Financial Officer, and Chief Operating Officer
Yes, thanks, Mike. I'd like to give a little more clarity on the Q3 guidance that we had given. On the Q2 earnings release, we gave a net sales range of $174 million to $176 million for Q3. If we add back the lost shipments due to the sale of our Miami division, we would have been at approximately $175 million for Q3 and that's right in the middle of the range and probably little north of that everything had turned out the way we had planned.
So, I'll just jump down to SG&A. SG&A for the third quarter of fiscal 2019 was $29.1 million compared to $28.2 million for the same period last year. The increase is mainly due to higher personnel cost of $0.2 million, $0.6 million of additional incentive stock compensation and $0.1 million of other items. As a percentage of net sales, SG&A was 17% for the third quarter of fiscal 2019, compared to 16.9% for the same period last year.
Other operating expense for the third quarter of fiscal 2019 was expense of $19.1 million compared to expense of $3.3 million for the same period last year. For the third quarter of fiscal 2019, other operating expenses were comprised mainly of $16.8 million costs associated with the sale of Miami division and $2.4 million in the amortization of intangible assets, offset by other income of $0.1 million.
Other operating expense for the same period last year consisted mainly of $1.1 million related to the restructuring of our Canadian operations and $2.3 million in the amortization of intangible assets, offsets by other income of $0.1 million. Operating income was $19.8 million for the third quarter of fiscal 2019 compared to operating income of $33.3 million for the same period in fiscal 2018. On an adjusted basis, operating income would have been $36.6 million for the third quarter of fiscal 2019 compared to adjusted operating income of $34.4 million for the same period of fiscal 2018.
For the third quarter of fiscal 2019, the Company reported net income of $16.2 million compared to net income of $23.8 million for the same period last year. On an adjusted basis, net income would have been $28.5 million for the third quarter of fiscal 2019 compared to adjusted net income of $25.7 million for the same period last year. Diluted earnings per share was $0.65 per share for the third quarter of fiscal 2019, compared to $0.97 per share for the same period last year. On an adjusted basis, diluted earnings per share for the third quarter of fiscal 2019 was $1.15 per share compared to an adjusted diluted EPS of $1.05 per share for the same period last year.
Turning to cash flow. The Company generated $21.1 million in cash from operating activities in the third quarter of fiscal 2019 compared to $28.5 million for the same period last year and $79 million in cash from operating activities for the nine-month period fiscal 2019, compared to $92.5 million for the same nine-month period last year.
Capital expenditures were $11.5 million in the third quarter of fiscal 2019, compared to $7.9 million for the same period last year. On a nine-month basis, CapEx was $29.2 million, compared to $20.5 million for the same nine-month period last year.
In the third quarter of fiscal 2019, the Company paid down $10.1 million of debt and for the nine-month period paid down $60.4 million of debt. Total debt as of December 29, 2018 was $114.6 million and cash on hand was $81.7 million. The day after the quarter closed on December 31, 2018, the Company paid down an additional $40 million of debt.
I'd now like to turn the call back over to the operator for the Q&A session.



Related Articles



RBC Bearings Inc (ROLL) Q4 2019 Earnings Call Transcript


3 Small Cap Growth Stocks With Boeing Exposure


RBC Bearings (ROLL) Q4 2018 Earnings Conference Call Transcript


Questions and Answers:
Operator
Thank you. (Operator Instructions) And our first question comes from Steve Barger with KeyBanc Capital Markets. Your line is open.
Kenneth Newman -- KeyBanc Capital Markets -- Analyst
Hey, good morning guys. This is Ken Newman on for Steve. Thanks for taking my question. I just wanted to touch back on the majors headlines with increasing build rates. Can you remind us of the content per airframe for a narrow body and a wide body and is this increase already contemplated within your internal forecast?
Michael J. Hartnett -- Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer
Yes, I don't have the exact content for wide body -- wide body or narrow body in front of me, but I'm sure Dan does. And is it included in which forecast, Ken?
Kenneth Newman -- KeyBanc Capital Markets -- Analyst
Yes, so in your internal forecast, as you were thinking about -- as you were thinking about this 4Q19, as you're thinking about your 2020 expectations, obviously you're not guiding to it, but are your capacity additions are those already kind of incorporated these new build rates?
Daniel A. Bergeron -- Director, Vice President, Chief Financial Officer, and Chief Operating Officer
Yes, I mean the reason that we're putting 150,000 square foot of new manufacturing floor place -- floor space in place is to support that growth. I mean, so we have committed contracts over a number of years and from those contracts and our content per aircraft, we can pretty much identify what our product demand is going to be by plant. And from that product demand, we can identify what we need for, what we have for capacity, what we need for capacity, what we might need for a floor space expansion and what we probably need for new processes, because so many of these products that go into the new aircraft are using coatings and other processes that typically have not been a staple for these manufacturing technologies in the past.
So, the world is -- the engineering world for aircraft design and manufacturing has changed a lot in the last five years and the market is rushing capacity in place to try to support the demand of the airframe producers. So yes, it's integrated into our -- into our outlook and I think throughout our FY20, which begins April 1st, you'll see increasing sales of that airframe product, as we turn on the floor space and achieve the approvals we need for these new processes and flow that to Boeing and the Boeing subs.
Kenneth Newman -- KeyBanc Capital Markets -- Analyst
Got it. It seems like non-auto maybe the non-tech industrial end markets are holding up pretty well. Is that what you're seeing? Are there any areas where you're focused on new market opportunities, or areas that kind of kick start growth within industrial?
Michael J. Hartnett -- Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer
Yes, well, I mean, there is a few things going on in the industrial side that are need to be considered. I mean, you can pretty much see what Caterpillar is doing and that's a major customer for us. And so we are developing products for Caterpillar that don't require lubrication and will last for the life of the system and so those are some of the new products that we're excited about.
And Caterpillar is equally excited and is in test. I think one of the industrial headwinds we'll have for FY20 is integrated in our numbers, if we include in the industrial side of our business, the marine products that we produce and sell to the defense industry for submarines. And because of the delay in some of the subcontracts, there is normally two to three boats per year that have to be built for the Virginia and the Columbia series of products.
So, we're going to have a gap here, where we're only going to build one boat for the Virginia and then we'll be back to two to two plus boats after that and that's going to happen in our FY20. So, that's a little bit of headwind on the industrial side for us. We expect to overcome that with just normal other industrial products.
Kenneth Newman -- KeyBanc Capital Markets -- Analyst
Okay. I'll just ask one more before getting back in the queue. Looking back over the past several years, operating margins are running at a level, which has been, I guess, considered peak over the last called five or 10 years. But so at a high level of performance right now, if we get into a mid-single digit organic growth environment, given the supply chain constraints that you're seeing, do you think you can drive margin expansion? And if so, how?
Michael J. Hartnett -- Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer
Yes, well we definitely think we have a plan to drive margin expansion. And the plan's a very solid one. And it's based on achieving internal processes for several of the products, where we buy those processes externally today. We've implemented the processes internally and are seeking OEM approval of those processes to be able to turn on our internal plans. And what that does for us is a couple of things, first of all, we can do the processes internally at less than half the cost of the external supplier.
Secondly, because of where our plants are and because of the -- there are so few suppliers that are -- that have the OEM approvals, it's not unusual for us to take product that is made in, let's say, Fairfield, Connecticut, put it on an airplane, ship it to California for special treatments, ship it back to Connecticut for final processing. So, that adds weeks of times for those product transit, as well as the expense of that transit. So, internalizing those processes, not only make sense for us in terms of the cost of the process, but the delay in the processing is eliminated and the efficiency of moving the materials through our plants is greatly increased.
Kenneth Newman -- KeyBanc Capital Markets -- Analyst
Got it. Thanks for the color.
Operator
Our next question comes from George Godfrey with CL King. Your line is open.
George Godfrey -- C. L. King & Associates, Inc. -- Analyst
Thank you and good morning. Thank you for taking my questions. For the fourth quarter guidance, $178 million to $180 million, can you tell me what's the organic growth rate embedded in that assumption?
Daniel A. Bergeron -- Director, Vice President, Chief Financial Officer, and Chief Operating Officer
It's about 2% to 3%.
George Godfrey -- C. L. King & Associates, Inc. -- Analyst
2% to 3%, OK. And that's down obviously from the 6.5% that was just reported. And Dan is the majority of that delta in the organic growth assumption, the supply chain issues that you referenced both external and internal?
Daniel A. Bergeron -- Director, Vice President, Chief Financial Officer, and Chief Operating Officer
Yes, it's mainly driven by the aerospace and defense side of the business. And obviously the comps on -- the year-over-year comps on the industrial get tougher and tougher, right. We grew the business at 20% last year, first nine months of this year at 10% so that's starting to catch up to us on that growth rate. So, as Mike said, we expect that we can still get that 2 times GDP type growth on the industrial side and then once we get through this bottleneck on the supply side and the in-sourcing side with aerospace, we should be back to the normalized growth rates that we are always expected.
George Godfrey -- C. L. King & Associates, Inc. -- Analyst
I see and my second question is, is the best you can in Q3, if you didn't have any supply chain issues and everything could operate at the capacity that customers were demanding either on a dollar level, you know $1.7 million would be 1% of organic growth on a percentage basis. Can you quantify how much that impacted the quarter approximately? Thanks.
Daniel A. Bergeron -- Director, Vice President, Chief Financial Officer, and Chief Operating Officer
We don't have a good estimate on that George. Mike do you have any thought on that?
Michael J. Hartnett -- Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer
Yes, well in the quarter we could -- on the aerospace side, we could sell as much as we could make. So, you know, to say that we could sell another $5 million worth of product in the quarter is probably not an understatement.
George Godfrey -- C. L. King & Associates, Inc. -- Analyst
Okay. So, organic growth rate could have easily been 3 percentage points higher or low-double digits, if the supply chain didn't have the issues. That's what I was trying to get at?
Michael J. Hartnett -- Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer
Yes, that's correct.
George Godfrey -- C. L. King & Associates, Inc. -- Analyst
Okay. And then last question, you talked about the treatment of the products being shipped to California, memory serves from the last call was also, you had your own backlog of equipment to get into Fairfield. Can you give us an update on where the backlog of the equipment that you ordered for this processing is? Thanks.
Michael J. Hartnett -- Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer
Yes, well we have -- you know we built in -- one of the plants that we built was about 60,000 square feet and it's in Oxford and its mission is to support Fairfield. That equipment is in -- some of that equipment is in -- and some of the equipment that is in will be operational and in production by the end of the fourth quarter. And then in the first quarter of next year, the balance of the equipment should be in place and subject to our ability to get (inaudible) on approvals from the OEM, that equipment can be in production by the end of June. Then the balance of the equipment will -- which is less critical, it's more it a plant consolidation exercise, will phase into the floor space over the balance of the year.
George Godfrey -- C. L. King & Associates, Inc. -- Analyst
Great. Thank you for taking my questions.
Operator
Our next question comes from Michael Ciarmoli with SunTrust. Your line is open.
Les Sulewski -- SunTrust Robinson Humphrey -- Analyst
Good morning guys. This is actually Les in for Michael.
Michael J. Hartnett -- Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer
Good morning.
Les Sulewski -- SunTrust Robinson Humphrey -- Analyst
Could you talk a little bit about the pricing environment, especially in the industrial side, were any weaknesses that you've seen there?
Michael J. Hartnett -- Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer
I think first on the industrial side, it's been pretty normal. We've been getting pricing, where we can get it, especially when it's associated to increase in raw material cost associated with tariffs are just normal inflation. Right now a lot of plants in the industry are constrained also, which is giving us a more favorable environment.
Les Sulewski -- SunTrust Robinson Humphrey -- Analyst
Okay. As far as the expansion in Connecticut goes and the facility additions, now, I believe you mentioned earlier in the year that you're looking for CapEx to be roughly 4.5% of sales, looks like it's probably about 100 bps higher than that. Any sort of puts and takes there, maybe some additional costs that you didn't foresee initially?
Michael J. Hartnett -- Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer
No, I just think, we completed the building here in Oxford, Connecticut a little quicker than we thought we would. So, a lot of that expense cut picked up in Q2, Q3. So, we finalized the whole building and we got our CO first week of January and so that was good news. We're a little ahead of schedule there and now we're populating with the equipment. But once these projects are behind us, this whole 150,000 expansion will be back to a normalized rate of 3.5% % range of sales for CapEx.
Les Sulewski -- SunTrust Robinson Humphrey -- Analyst
Okay, got it. And I guess on the -- as far as the book-to-bill, I believe it just came in a little bit below 1 end of 3Q. Was there any impact to the backlog from the Miami divestiture?
Daniel A. Bergeron -- Director, Vice President, Chief Financial Officer, and Chief Operating Officer
Yes, and just very small. A lot of their business was in and out business in the quarter, so wouldn't have been a huge number. There is -- as I think Mike -- Dr. Hartnett has talked about this on previous calls with some of our larger aerospace customers now, a lot of the orders don't even go through our backlog because we're picking up the orders through a portal. So you never get the order into the day you ship it, you go into the portal, you get the order, they give you the barcode to ship the products and your shipping. So, it's in and out within the quarter, which in previous years, you would have seen that built up into our backlog number. So, but yes, Miami not a big impact on the backlog, maybe a few million and that's about it
Les Sulewski -- SunTrust Robinson Humphrey -- Analyst
Got it. Thank you. I guess just one last one and I'll jump back in the queue. Just a housekeeping on the -- what's the normalized tax rate you'd expect for the year now?
Daniel A. Bergeron -- Director, Vice President, Chief Financial Officer, and Chief Operating Officer
I think around that, you know, from a normalized -- we have a lot of falling through it this year, but we should be normalized in around 20%.
Les Sulewski -- SunTrust Robinson Humphrey -- Analyst
Got it. Thank you.
Operator
Our next question comes from Kristine Liwag with Bank of America Merrill Lynch. Your line is open.
Kristine Liwag -- Bank of America Merrill Lynch -- Analyst
Hey, good morning guys.
Michael J. Hartnett -- Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer
Good morning, Kristine.
Kristine Liwag -- Bank of America Merrill Lynch -- Analyst
With the supply chain constraints that you're facing, are you delivering on time for your customers? And then how much of a slack is there in a supply chain, if you're not?
Daniel A. Bergeron -- Director, Vice President, Chief Financial Officer, and Chief Operating Officer
For the -- you know in terms of delivering on time, I think for 98% of the customers, we are delivering on time, for a 100% -- for the other 2%, we are struggling and doing extraordinary things in order to cover the supply need. What was the second part of your question?
Kristine Liwag -- Bank of America Merrill Lynch -- Analyst
And how much supply chain slack is there in the market, if you're not delivering on time. Because and I would have assumed that you could be -- are you a bottleneck for the production rate ramp?
Daniel A. Bergeron -- Director, Vice President, Chief Financial Officer, and Chief Operating Officer
In those 2% cases, I would say we are.
Kristine Liwag -- Bank of America Merrill Lynch -- Analyst
And which programs for those be?
Michael J. Hartnett -- Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer
Those would be the probably the 737 program.
Kristine Liwag -- Bank of America Merrill Lynch -- Analyst
I see. And then with the struggles that you're having there, do you have to pay a penalty, is there something that you might have to take a charge on, is that goes along?
Michael J. Hartnett -- Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer
No, so far so good on that Kristine. I think, we're through that the -- through the worst part of the situation now, you know, the interesting part is the -- a lot of the suppliers that we need in order to complete the product are our bottleneck. And although we get the product to the supplier on time, the supplier will tell us, we can do it four-week and then four weeks passes and they say, well, we didn't get to it we need another four weeks and we don't have that kind of time in the schedule. So, that's where the problem really has been acute.
So, the interesting thing is, we have internal processes for the most part that we can apply to satisfy the sort of production requirements for the design and those processes are approved by the OEM. So, when the OEM says, what can we do to get parts, we say you can approve our processes and this is our -- these are our credentials, these are our approvals by the current quality societies et cetera.
And in some cases we get that approval within an hour. So, that's really accelerated our program and has really eliminated the supply constraints that we were under for the third quarter in some product areas -- in the most acute product areas.
Kristine Liwag -- Bank of America Merrill Lynch -- Analyst
I see. And then in 1Q and 2Q '20, when your 150,000 square feet addition comes on line, how much of a margin to headwind, or how much headwind to margin do you expect to see there for those quarters?
Daniel A. Bergeron -- Director, Vice President, Chief Financial Officer, and Chief Operating Officer
Well, that's a hard question to answer, because if you take half of that capacity is going into a plant, that's going to supply these external processes that we buy outside. So, our hope there is that there is maybe a little bit of tailwind, and no headwind as we change those processes from external purchase to internal supply. And in the other cases, where we're adding floor space, it's for product sales. I mean, it's absolutely -- the floor space should be more than covered by additional revenues.
Kristine Liwag -- Bank of America Merrill Lynch -- Analyst
I see. And lastly from me, when I look at the moving pieces of fiscal year '20, it seems like you've got a few significant tailwinds to your business. You've got the submarine ramps and for calendar year '19, there is a F-35 ramp going from 90 to 130. You've got the 737 ramp and you've got 787 ramp and you've got your market share wins on those programs. When I think about 2020, what would prevent your business from seeing double-digit growth for the entire enterprise, when I see these tailwinds? Are there anything that -- is there anything that you're concerned about, that could prevent you from seeing that double-digit growth for next year?
Michael J. Hartnett -- Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer
Well, if you go to the sub program Kristine, that FY20 is going to be the one boat year for the Virginia. Normally we have a two boat year for the Virginia, that's going to be a one boat year for the Virginia, because of the delay in contract finalization. Now I think the second half of '20, the Virginia, -- we may see 1.5 boats that year because of the second half contract should be finalized and we're producing at a more normalized rate.
So, I think that's probably the only headwind we have on the industrial side. The rest of it's pretty normal, if the price of oil gets -- starts to accelerate again, everybody would be fracking again, there won't be enough bearings to frack everything that needs to be fracked. And we'll be back running seven days a week making bearings for fracking machines. So, a lot of that is dependent upon what happens to the price of these commodities. And the aircraft business is just going to be -- it's going to be strong, it's going to be as strong as we can keep up to and that's probably in most of our aircraft plants.
Kristine Liwag -- Bank of America Merrill Lynch -- Analyst
Great. Thank you guys.
Operator
Our next question comes from Pete Skibitski with Alembic Global. Your line is open.
Pete Skibitski -- Alembic Global Advisors -- Analyst
Hey, good morning, guys. Mike, one thing I was -- somebody could help me. I'm so confused on defense. Was defense revenue down in the third quarter and are you expecting it down in the fourth quarter as well?
Michael J. Hartnett -- Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer
Let's see, so are you talking on the aerospace side?
Pete Skibitski -- Alembic Global Advisors -- Analyst
Well, the defense portion, I guess within either segment?
Michael J. Hartnett -- Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer
Okay. So, on the aerospace side, defense that goes through distribution was up 17.6%, so it's a $1.848 million compared to $1.571 million last year and on aerospace OEM defense, it was down 2.5%, it was at $18.256 million compared to $18.727 million last year. And on the industrial side, the marine business was up 16.6%, $10.223 million from $8.765 million last year. Does that help Pete?
Pete Skibitski -- Alembic Global Advisors -- Analyst
It does. Okay, yes. So, Mike touched on I think defense orders, and he meant that literally that orders were low this quarter on the defense side and that will start flowing through to weaker sales. It sounds like in the first half of 2020 and then maybe some recovery in the back half of 2020?
Michael J. Hartnett -- Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer
Yes.
Pete Skibitski -- Alembic Global Advisors -- Analyst
Okay, OK. And so you guys are thinking, I guess, overall in aerospace, the back half of 2020 is when things really get interesting because defense starts to recover, particularly with the submarines and that you've done all of the in-sourcing aspects completed and you start to ramp on the commercial side more so, is that, would you say that's accurate?
Michael J. Hartnett -- Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer
That's how we see it.
Pete Skibitski -- Alembic Global Advisors -- Analyst
Okay, OK. And Mike the 2% delivery struggles, are you going to kind of complete those problems even before the in-sourcing is complete, or will that kind of linger on until all the capacity build out and the in sourcing is done?
Michael J. Hartnett -- Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer
Well, the most acute delivery problems that we've had Pete that's what we did over our Christmas holidays, what did you do? Those problems were taken care of by an accelerated approval that we had from Boeing on our special processes. So, those problems, as of this morning are far behind us.
Pete Skibitski -- Alembic Global Advisors -- Analyst
Got it. Got it. And then Mike, in terms of tariff issues, anything hitting you at all, trying to relate it or any other tariff issues negatively impacting revenue?
Michael J. Hartnett -- Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer
Yes, well, the tariff issues are something special to manage, it just gives you one more thing to manage. And so particularly on the material side, we have to calculate for each one of our materials what it was and what it's going to be. And then what we paid for steel last year and what we're going to have to pay for steel this year. And so there are changes. And then we pass through, we immediately calculate what that does to our product margins. And then we refer to our contracts to make sure that we were smart enough, when we negotiated the terms that we had a material pass-through clause as part of the terms. In 99.99% of the cases, we do have that clause. And so we're able to pass it through either as a surcharge or as a new price.
Pete Skibitski -- Alembic Global Advisors -- Analyst
Got it. Okay. Thanks guys. I'll get back in queue.
Operator
Thank you. (Operator Instructions) Our next question comes from Josh Sullivan with Seaport Global. Your line is open.
Josh Sullivan -- Seaport Global Holdings LLC -- Analyst
Hey, good morning.
Michael J. Hartnett -- Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer
Hey Josh.
Josh Sullivan -- Seaport Global Holdings LLC -- Analyst
Just, I mean, I think you might have asked this, but curious on the supply constraints in aerospace. How does it compare airframe versus the jet engine vertical? There has been some conversation of increased resources at the jet engine level, just curious if you could comment between the two?
Michael J. Hartnett -- Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer
Well, it's mainly for us, it's mainly -- the constraints are mainly felt in airframe. On the engine side, life is very busy right now, negotiating new contracts on the engine side. Our ability to supply the engine components is very good. It's not -- it hasn't been tested and it looks like it won't be tested .
So, the action on the engine components side is one of negotiating new contracts and putting those in place with the terms that we can all feel comfortable with and the pricing that we can all feel comfortable with and sort of off we go. So, engine -- engine business is a big check-the-box kind of status and so both the leap and the gear turbo fan, we have absolutely no problem at all keeping up to demand. On the -- and that's -- those are special plans that we have -- that are focused on engines almost exclusively.
And then on the airframe side, we -- I think we talked about the constraints in the internal processes that we're incorporating and the industry-lead-time is a lot of these products right now is reported to be out of 52 weeks to 56 weeks. So, it's -- the industry is very, very constrained that being able to produce the product, the airframe builders.
Josh Sullivan -- Seaport Global Holdings LLC -- Analyst
And then just as follow-up on those contract negotiations, you just mentioned. Is there any change in the structure of those versus previous ones? Are they looking at a longer duration? Are you guys going after more market share, is there any I know it's sensitive, but just any qualitative comments there?
Michael J. Hartnett -- Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer
Yes, well, there's a lot of terms that we negotiate these contracts with people that are paid to negotiate contracts that are in the business for real and they really know what they're doing. So, there's a lot of terms that to be dealt with that have to be where your point -- your point of view has to be argued and a compromise reached.
So, -- but we get there. I mean the customer needs the product and when we have a good product and often isn't above pricing. When it comes to pricing, you know, the price is one thing and then making sure that the price and the margin is protected over those number of years is the next thing through either material pass-through or cost of sales pass-through that where there is some other extraneous factors that might be influencing the cost of sales, it's not material. So, yes, I mean it's a lot of work. I mean, we spend hours and hours and hours negotiating these terms.
Josh Sullivan -- Seaport Global Holdings LLC -- Analyst
Okay. And then just one last one on the M&A front. You know are you finding more opportunities on the industrial side, or is the aerospace side more interesting? And then just can you remind us of what some of the hurdle rates are for attractive M&A for you guys?
Michael J. Hartnett -- Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer
Well, yes, we find both sides of the business attractive to us. And it varies with regard to, you know, who is on the market at any given point in time. We had -- we made a very large bid in December and it wasn't successful, the seller decided to keep the business. I think they were testing the market on its valuation and we were little disappointed not to achieve that. That was on the aerospace side.
But we continue to -- we continue to work the process and we've seen some very interesting industrial product deals that have been presented to us that are attractive and the multiples -- are where -- it's too much private equity money chasing these deals. So, they become a little expensive.
Josh Sullivan -- Seaport Global Holdings LLC -- Analyst
